title: El Chapo’s son arrested then freed again as violent gun battle breaks out
text:
Ovido Guzman was released after armed fighters swarmed police (Picture: REUTERS)

An intense gunfight with heavy weapons and burning vehicles blocking roads paralysed the Mexican city of Culiacan after police located drug lord ‘El Chapo’ Guzman’s son.

Armed fighters ambushed police after they captured Ovidio Guzman Lopez, who is wanted in the U.S. on drug trafficking charges.

Mexican security secretary Alfonso Durazo said 30 members of the National Guard and army were patrolling in Culiacan when they were fired on from a house.

They repelled the attack and inside the house found Ovidio Guzman Lopez.

The house was then surrounded by heavily armed gunmen who had ‘a greater force’ and authorities decided to suspend the operation – meaning Ovido was released.

Advertisement

Culiacan, the capital of Sinaloa state, exploded into violence when the fight broke out, with armed civilians in trucks racing through the city’s centre and shooting what appeared to be sniper rifles and machine guns.

Videos published on social media showed a scene resembling a war zone, with gunmen clad in black ski masks firing mounted machine guns from trucks as vehicles burned.

People could be seen running for cover while other drivers reversed frantically to get away from the clashes.

Ricardo Gonzalez, a worker in the state’s congress who shut himself up in his house after picking up his 15-year-old son from school, told a reporter that ‘nothing is working’.

A burning bus was alight by cartel gunmen to block a road during clashes with federal forces (Picture: REUTERS)

Vehicles burn in a street of Culiacan which exploded into violence over the capture of Ovido Guzman (Picture: AFP)

Residents say it’s the worst violence they have seen in over a decade (Picture: EPA)

A bullet ridden vehicle abandoned in a street of Culiacan (Picture: AFP)

The violence has brought the city to a standstill (Picture: EFE)

He said: ‘There is a psychosis. No one knows what is going on but everyone is afraid and they have told us to not come in to work tomorrow’.

Gonzalez said people outside the city were ‘blocked’ from coming back in, adding he had not seen such violence for almost a decade, when the Sinaloa Cartel was experiencing an internal war.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Sinaloa is home to the cartel by the same name, which was led by notorious drug lord ‘El Chapo’ Guzman.

Guzman was sentenced to life in prison in the United States in July and has many children wanted on suspicion of drug trafficking.

Ivan Archivaldo Guzman and Jesus Alfredo Guzman are known as ‘los Chapitos’ or ‘the little Chapos’ are his best known sons and are believed to currently run their father’s business.

El Chapo’s son Ovido is wanted in the US for drug trafficking (Picture: AFP)

El Chapo Guzman, the former head of Mexico’s Sinaloa Cartel (Picture: AP)

Fighters in black masks could be seen firing bullets from trucks when the violence erupted (Picture: Twitter / Carlos ZigaPrez)

Civilians seeking shelter during clashes between armed groups and federal forces in Culiacan Picture: EL DEBATE DE SINALOA)

Jose Luis Gonzalez Meza, a lawyer for ‘El Chapo’s’ family, told The Associated Press that Guzman’s family has said ‘Ovidio is alive and free’ but that he had no more details about what had happened.

Sinaloa public safety director Cristobal Castaneda told Milenio television that there were people wounded but did not provide a casualty figure.

Graphic images from the scene of the violence show dead bodies on the streets next to bullet ridden cars.

Graphic images from the scene show dead bodies next to bullet ridden cars (Picture: REUTERS)

The body of a victim lies in a street of Culiacan (Picture:AFP)

Smoke from burning cars engulfs Culiacan (Picture: AP)

Cartel gunmen are seen near a burning truck during clashes with federal forces following the detention of Ovidio (Picture: Reuters)

Sinaloa’s soccer club Dorados announced that it had cancelled its game Thursday due to security concerns.

Advertisement

School classes were cancelled and there is no public transportation.
